bioghist.p: Wharton Huber (1877-1942) was an ornithologist and a mammalogist. He was assistant, and later associate, curator of the collection of birds and mammals at the Academy of Natural Sciences from 1920 to 1934. In 1934 he became curator of mammals, a post he held until his death in 1942. He was a three-time president of the Delaware Valley Ornithological Club, and also a staff member of the Wistar Institute of Philadelphia, where he assisted in making anatomical preparations. An enthusiastic collector and field man, he excelled in photographing birds and mammals in their native haunts.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of photographs and papers of Wharton Huber. Photographs make up the bulk of the collection and include glass and film negatives, contact sheets, and prints. Subjects Huber photographed include birds, animals, plants, landscapes, Apache Indians, and Huber's home and family. His photographs document his trips to Nicaragua, Cape Cod, the Pacific coast, and New Mexico. Papers in the collection include diaries from his trips to Nicargua (1922) and the Queen Charlotte Islands (1930); correspondence about the collection of skins and specimens; letters of introduction; brochures and announcements; and several pamphlets for the Ludwick Lecture Series.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
